visit to the harbor, this would spread to
other parts of downtown and eventually
the entire city.

In 1972, Pier | along the northern
shoreline was rebuilt for the U.S.F. Constel-
lation, built in 1797 and the oldest ship in
the U.S. Navy. The first of the Inner Har-
bor’s public attractions was in place.

In 1973, the city shifted the City Fair to
the Inner Harbor. This event, begun in 1969
to celebrate the City’s neighborhoods, is a
deliberate effort on the part of Baltimore to
create good feelings about the city. The fair
has grown into an immense, enthusiastic
September spectacle; an estimated two
million persons attended the weekend
event in 1983. Part of the resistance that
later developed to plans for some of the
buildings along the edge of the Inner Har-
bor stemmed in part from the public’s fear
that the City Fair would be displaced as
Pratt and Light Streets were developed with
major new buildings. The fair was relocated
in 1981 to Marketplace, the Pratt Street
Boulevard, and Piers 5 and 6.

Another milestone occurred in 1972,
completion of the first building in the
Inner Harbor area, Christ Lutheran’s Harbor
Apartments south of the McCormick spice
factory. In 1973, one of Baltimore’s tallest
buildings, the U.S.F. & G. home office was
completed.



Light St., Harborplace, 1983

As the country observed its bicentenial
in 1976, Baltimore took advantage of one of
the most spectacular events created for the
celebration, the Tall Ships. A special com-
mittee of city residents and local corpora-
tions worked to attract a major visit of this
fleet of the world’s sailing ships. A two
week long celebration was planned. More
tall ships visited Baltimore than any other
_ 3 q American port except New York and New-
. romenadade

, looking south, City Fair, 1973




Inner Harbor Manaemet 83

port. The area’s residents were caught up
in the excitement and welcomed the crews
and visitors with the kind of fervor unheard
of since Baltimore greeted Lafayette on his
triumphant tour 150 years earlier. Over two
and a half million visitors, many from the
Midwest and adjoining states, poured into
the city. The event also drew visitors from
the Washington and Baltimore suburbs and
introduced them to a newly emerging
Inner Harbor.

By 1976 there was enough physical
evidence of the downtown/harbor transfor-
mation to come to make it attractive. The
number of buildings either underway or
occupied grew each year. The IBM office
building near Pratt and Light Streets, was
finished in 1975. The Maryland Science
Center designed by architect Edward Durell
Stone at the harbor’s southwestern edge
was opened in 1976, and playing fields
were completed at the south side of the
harbor. 1976 also saw the dedication of the
Harbor Campus of the Community College
of Baltimore. The C & P Telephone Co.
completed its building at Pratt and con-
struction was underway on the World
Trade Center, the harbor’s dominant struc-
ture, which opened in 1977.

Beyond the one-time spectacle of
the Tall ships, the Inner Harbor area was
(and is) used all summer by city-spon-
sored, weekend ethnic festivals and other
activities. The green open space behind the
shoreline promenade became the city’s
front yard, the place to gather, celebrate,
and enjoy city life.

After the success of the Tall Ships visit,
the future of the Inner Harbor as a gather-
ing place fer the region’s citizens was
sealed. What wasn’t settled yet was the final
nature of that place and how people
wanted to see it used.

The Charles Center and Inner Harbor
projects were nearly uninterrupted success
stories to this point. Nothing as complex
and innovative as these undertakings would
be without some difficulties.

An illustration of the latter occurred in
1977 when Baltimore was negotiating to
bring a hotgl to the Inner Harbor. A major
new hotel was needed to make the city’s
planned Convention Center (opened in
1979) attractive to conventions. But the
drawing power of the Inner Harbor was
still not clear to investors in 1977. As Mayor
Schaefer has recalled “We were practically
on our knees to get some hotel chain to
make a commitment.” In fact the first two
hotel developers selected were unable to
carry out their plans. In order to make it
possible for the Hyatt chain to build in the
Inner Harbor, Baltimore obtained a $10-
million federal Urban Development Action
Grant which, together with a $2 million set-
tlement from an earlier hotel developer,
